alert.note: Alert for Daviess; Greene; Knox (Indiana) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued March 07 at 11:00PM EST until March 13 at 9:46PM EST by NWS Indianapolis
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following river in Indiana... White River. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following river in Indiana... White River. .Ongoing and renewed flooding will continue or develop along portions of the East Fork White, White, and Wabash Rivers over the next 24 to 48 hours and beyond. River stages are rising again due to the one to over two and a half inches of rain received from Saturday night through this morning. Minor flooding is expected at nearly all locations, which primarily impacts river roads, parks, and agricultural land. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL LATE SUNDAY EVENING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...White River at Newberry. * WHEN...Until late Sunday evening. * IMPACTS...At 19.0 feet, Extensive agricultural flooding is in progress. Some state and county roads flood. County Road 600 W just north of river flooded by possibly more than two feet of water for a considerable distance in Mary Long Cutoff Area. County Roads 900 W and 750 S begin to flood in Greene County. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:30 PM EST Monday the stage was 13.8 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 9:30 PM EST Monday was 13.8 feet. - Forecast...The river will rise to 18.8 feet Thursday evening. It will then fall below flood stage late Sunday morning to 7.0 feet and begin rising again Tuesday, March 15. It will rise to 7.9 feet Tuesday, March 15. It will then fall again and remain below flood stage. - Flood stage is 13.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding. Flooding is occurring or is imminent. Most flood related deaths occur in automobiles. Do not attempt to cross water covered bridges, dips, or low water crossings. Never try to cross a flowing stream, even a small one, on foot. To escape rising water find another route over higher ground. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov/ind. The next statement should be issued Tuesday afternoon by around 400 PM EST /300 PM CST/.
